Use case: Kinases are proteins that attach phosphate groups to other molecules, acting like switches to turn cell processes on or off. This regulation affects growth, metabolism, and cell division. Because many diseases such as cancer involve overactive kinases, drugs often target these proteins to restore balance.
Use Case References: Cohen P. Protein kinasesâ€”the major drug targets of the twenty-first century? Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2002) https://doi.org/10.1038/nrd773

Set Name: Regulating Hormone and Nerve Signals (GPCR Receptors)
GO Terms: G protein-coupled receptor activity; G protein-coupled receptor signaling pathway
Use case: GPCRs (G protein-coupled receptors) sit on the cell surface and detect signals like hormones, neurotransmitters, or smells. When activated, they trigger cascades inside the cell. This makes them essential for many senses and body processes, which is why more than a third of modern medicines act on GPCRs.
Use Case References: Hauser AS et al. Pharmacogenomics of GPCR Drug Targets. Cell (2017) https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2017.09.001

Set Name: Controlling Drug and Ion Flow (Transporters & Channels)
GO Terms: Transmembrane transporter activity; Ion channel activity
Use case: Transporters and channels are like gates in the cell membrane that control the entry and exit of substances such as ions, nutrients, and drugs. They influence how cells communicate, get nutrients, and maintain electrical signals. Targeting these proteins can change how substances move in or out of cells, which is important in treating diseases like hypertension or epilepsy.
Use Case References: Giacomini KM et al. Membrane transporters in drug development. Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2010) https://doi.org/10.1038/nrd3028

GO Terms: DNA-binding transcription factor activity; Regulation of transcription by RNA polymerase II
Use case: Transcription factors are proteins that control when and how strongly genes are turned on or off. They shape how cells develop and respond to signals. Problems with transcription factors can lead to diseases like cancer or developmental disorders, so understanding them can help design therapies that influence gene activity.
Use Case References: Lambert SA et al. The human transcription factors. Cell (2018) https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2018.01.029

GO Terms: Immune response; Cytokine activity; Receptor binding
Use case: Proteins in the immune and inflammation response coordinate how the body defends itself against infections or injury. Cytokines and receptors help cells communicate during immune reactions. By targeting these proteins, drugs can boost immune responses, as in vaccines or cancer immunotherapy, or reduce harmful inflammation in autoimmune diseases.
Use Case References: Dinarello CA. Overview of the IL-1 family in innate inflammation and acquired immunity. Immunological Reviews (2018) https://doi.org/10.1111/imr.12615
